hypotheses: High ACT subsidies increase ACT uptake but worsen targeting (more ACTs given to malaria-negative individuals).
Reducing the ACT subsidy improves targeting (increases the share of ACT takers who are malaria-positive) without large reductions in access for high-risk groups (children).
Subsidizing RDTs increases testing rates substantially.
Even when RDTs are subsidized, compliance with negative test results is imperfect and RDT subsidies alone have limited short-term impact on reducing over-treatment.
claim.statement: Subsidizing antimalarial drugs (ACTs) substantially increases access but can worsen targeting (leading to over-treatment); subsidizing RDTs raises testing rates but has limited short-term impact on reducing inappropriate ACT use.

data.source: Administrative drug shop transaction records, endline household survey data, and a symptoms-to-positivity database constructed from RDT results
data.wave_or_subset: Analysis focuses on first illness episodes reported in the endline survey and on voucher redemptions / drug shop visits during the four-month study window
data.sample_size: Approximately 2,789 households enrolled; administrative data captured over 1,700 drug shop visits in four months
data.unit_of_analysis: Household-level illness episodes and individual drug shop visits (individual/illness episode)
data.notes: Data sources include voucher redemption logs (drug shop administrative data), an endline household illness/treatment survey, and a symptoms database mapping symptoms to RDT outcomes. Predicted malaria positivity index constructed from symptoms (correlation with RDT results ≈ 0.48).

method.description: A randomized controlled trial where households were randomized to different subsidy regimes for ACTs (no subsidy, and ACT subsidies at approximately 92%, 88%, and 80%) and to RDT subsidy arms (free, subsidized, small refundable payment). Vouchers were distributed to observe redemption behavior at local drug shops; drug shop transactions and RDT results (when used) were recorded. Endline surveys collected illness episodes and treatment choices. Regression analysis with household-clustered robust standard errors and controls was used to estimate effects on access and targeting.
steps: Enumerate and enroll households meeting inclusion criteria (rural households distant from health facilities).
Randomize households into treatment arms varying ACT subsidy levels (no subsidy, ~92%, ~88%, ~80%) and RDT subsidy conditions.
Distribute vouchers to households according to assigned treatment arms.
Enable participating drug shops to accept vouchers and record transaction-level data (medicines purchased, symptoms, RDT results when administered).
Offer a 'surprise RDT' to measure underlying malaria positivity unbiased by pre-selection.
Conduct an endline household survey approximately four months after voucher distribution to collect self-reported illness episodes, treatments sought, and medicines purchased.
Construct a symptoms-based predicted malaria positivity index using RDT-labeled cases.

Estimate intent-to-treat effects and treatment effects using regressions with household-clustered robust standard errors, controlling for strata and household head age (and other baseline covariates as needed).
Perform robustness checks (e.g., false discovery rate adjustments) and subgroup analyses (by age group, subsidy level).
method.models: Linear regression (OLS) specifications estimating differences in means across randomized arms; regressions include strata fixed effects and control for household head age; robust standard errors clustered at the household level. Additional analyses use predicted-malaria indices and administrative RDT results.
method.outcome_variable: Primary outcomes: Access (share of illness episodes treated with ACTs) and Targeting (share of ACT takers who are malaria-positive). Secondary outcomes: RDT take-up, voucher redemption rates, treatment source (drug shop vs. health center), antibiotic use.
method.independent_variables: Randomized treatment indicators for ACT subsidy level (92%, 88%, 80%, none) and RDT subsidy condition (free, subsidized, refundable), interaction terms for subsidy levels and RDT availability in some specifications.
method.control_variables: Strata fixed effects (randomization strata), household head age, and baseline covariates as used for balance and adjusted regressions.
method.tools_software: not stated (analysis described as regression-based with clustered robust standard errors; specific software or packages not reported)

results.summary: Large retail ACT subsidies substantially increased ACT uptake and drug shop care-seeking but led to considerable over-treatment (many ACT takers were malaria-negative). Higher subsidies (e.g., ~92%) increased ACT use markedly but worsened targeting; lowering subsidies (to ~80%) improved targeting, particularly by reducing inappropriate adult voucher redemptions while preserving children's access. Subsidized RDTs substantially increased testing rates (roughly doubling testing) and had high voucher redemption for RDTs (~80%), but many individuals with negative RDT results still obtained ACTs, so RDT subsidies produced limited short-term reductions in over-treatment. Welfare analysis suggested an ~80% ACT subsidy could be more cost-effective than very high subsidies by treating more malaria-positive individuals per ACT dispensed and reducing treatment of malaria-negative cases.

numerical_results.unit: proportion (share of illness episodes treated with ACTs)

numerical_results.effect_size: Increase in share malaria-positive among ACT takers from 0.56 to 0.75 when lowering subsidy from 92% to 80%
RDT subsidy increased testing by roughly 15–26 percentage points (doubling testing rates reported)
Approximately 80% redemption even when small user fee charged
ACT access increased by roughly 16–23 percentage points relative to control (control ≈19%)
